 W lsbnry, in the County of Litchfeld, and state of Connecticut, was, by the Hon. Superior Court, holden at Litchfield, within and tor said county, on the third Tuesday of February, 1927, deemed and adjudged to be an insolvent debtor, within the true intent & meaning ofthe statute law of this state, enti- tied "An Act to authorize the Superior Court to grant relief in certain cases of insolvency" and Whereas, we the subscribers were by said court appointed Commissioners to receive, adjust, and ascertain the several debts due and owing by said insolvent debtor, and he having in conformity of said court assigned to us, the said commissioners, his estate on oath: These are therefore to give notice to the several creditors of said insolvent debtor that we shall meet for the purpose aforesaid, at the dwelIing-house of Jeremiah Bushnell, in Salisbury, aforesaid, on the first mondays of April and May, and the 3dmonday of Sept. next, at two o'clock, P. M. on each of said days; when and where they may appear il they see cause, and exhibit and prove their respective debts or claims against said insol- vent debtor.

 Dated at Salisbury this l4th day of March A. ID. 1897.

NOTICE.

Thanks to my lucky star ? exclaimed old Jacobs, standing near lofty moun- tain, and looking with infinite complacen- cy at the property which he had purchac- ed at the Tontine Coffee House-'Thanks to my lucky star I am worth one hund- red thousand dollars !-'I am worth at least one hundred thousand dollars ? said he, fairly scraped together! think will buy a ship for Jack; Tom shall be coun- sellor; Patty, yes, Patty shall marry the English Ambassador

 'I am worth one hundred thousand dol- lars ! l was just sixty-6ve last Christmas, 1 am yet hale and strong. Go to: I'll withdraw from the bustle of the world, and the busy hum of the exchange. I'll retire and enjoy myself

 Good y continued old Jacobs, manful- ly striding up the mountains side-'Good! l am worth at least one hundred thousand dollars! Aye here I'll build me a warm mansion-there, I'll plant my orchard on this side will have my summer-house round younder angle, we'll run up the stable-and here will dig my ice-house. What must have all those unsightly wooden houses blocking up my view No matter can purchase them of my broth CT merchant, MT. Hicks and then every one ofthem shall come down.

 Consider, sir, for moment.' observed old Jacobs land agent, consider what will these poor people do, ifyou pull down their huts 1? 'Do-do'-let them do as they can: 'tis no concern of mine. And hark ye Mir. Agent, do you see that mill, that makes such a noisy clack do you see, I say, how its wheel obstructs the stream that wa ters my grounds ? Come no words-that shall come down too.'

 50 sagely determined old Jacobs, and ne went home pleased with the project oi hls brain. He supped heartily-he took hls hot punch-cracked his jokes-smok- ed four cigars--and went to bed.

 A fit of apoplexy came on suddenl, at night, and-old Jacobs never more a. woke.

 The unsightly wooden houses, there, fore, sill stand and their inhabitants
OLD JACOBS.

A small DWELLING HOUSE, and EA- nine Ares of LAND pleasantly situated on the county road leading from Litchfeld to Roxbury, suitably divided into Moving, Pas ture, and Woodland. Said land is we'll wa tered with two never failing springs, one of which is near the house. It is good stand for mechanic of almost any description, particularly blacksmith. Should the pur- chaser wish for more land, it can be obtained adjoining the above,-all of which will ke sold on reasonable terms. For further par ticulars, enquire of the subscriber on the pre- misses. JOHN PARISH.

 Washington, March 22d, 1927. Al
FOR SALE.

THE OIL MILL, late the property of .-l Moses Seymour, Junr deceased, situa- ted in Bradleys-Ville, town of Litchfeld;- ALSO, the Carding machines, and Stand, late the property of said Seymour, situated about one mile South-westerly from said Oil Mill. Said Mill and Machines stand upon the large and never failing steam which issues from Litchfeld Lake,-have well built and perma- nent dams. and are in good repair. The Ma chimes consist of a Double Machine, Single Machine, and a Picker. The water power at both these establishments is abundant, and may be advantageously applied to any other kind ofmills or machinery, as well as to those now in operation there. For further partic- ulars enquire of DAVID c. SANFORD.

 Litchfeld, March 23, 1927. fl
FOR SALE.

averv respect.-There were few in that illus trious assembly whose judgment was more respected or whose opinions had more weight. A strong reason; firm will a stead(ast, in- trepid patriotism simple but nervous elo- cutiOn: venerable appearacce under the plarnest garb the credit of primitive virtue i; efficient readiness and unwearied assiduity in the business of COmmittees-all combined to render him one of the real leaders of the rev olution: to inspire universal confidence and involve him in the most arduous parliament ary labors. He re appeared iD 1765 as one of the delegates from Connecticut, toiled in cessantiy in Committees during 1776, and es- pecialy served that which prepared and reported the Declaration of Independence. MT. Jefferson, in letter relating to him, ob- servcs-"I served with him in the old Con- gress in the years 1775 and l776. He was very able and logical debater in that body steady in the principles of the revolution; al ways at the post of duty much employed in the business of Committees, and particularly was of the Committee of Dr. Franklin, MT. J. Adams and myself for preparing the Decla- ration of Independence" He was also suc- cessively member of War and Ordnance, of the Treasury board and of the Marine com mittee. During the whole revolutionary strug- gle, he manifested a dauntless spirit as we'll as an ndefatigable zeal.

 In 1784 when New Haven was incorpora- ted, he was elected to the office of Mayor of the city, which he held for the remainder ol his life. About the same period, he was as- sociated with another of the Judges of the Superior Court, in the task of revising and digesting the statutes 0f Connecticut, SO as to produce an improved code for the State. This oppressive service was performed with his usual conscientiousness and success. In 1787, he was appointed a delegate to the General Convention to frame the Federal Constitution of the United States. One of his colleagues was the celebrated Oliver Els worth, who held the office of associate judge of the same court, and wLo as he himself de clared had made MT. Sherman his model in his youth. The venerable President Adams

 mentions that '' he never saw two men more

 alike, except that the late Chief Justice Els worth had the advantage of a liberal educa ton, and somewhat more extensive reading , Both were conspicuous in the Convention fo , the earnestness and usefulness of their coop eration in tho glorious work of that body Sherman wrote series of essays under thu 1 signature of" Citizen," in favor of the con

 stitution, which are affirmed to have materi

 ally contributed to procure that full majority

 by which it was ratified in Connecticut. Wher I it went into operation, he was elected rep resentative in Congress, and though vergins toward his 7Oth year, took deep interest & active part in the proceedings of the new House.

 At the expiration of his first term, he was translated to the Senate, among whom he was never found backward, either in debate oI committee service, touching the various impOr- tant subjects which then came under discus sion. Providence, however, allowed him but two years more of a race thus signaized, in public and private, by dispositions and endea- yours which were well adapted to propitiate Divine favour for another life. He died at New-Haven, on the Sd July, 179S, aged sev- enty two. He had been from his youth de- vout christian, and constant reader of the Scriptures. He maintained correspondence, at different times, on abstruse points of the ology and metaphysics, with some of the most erudite and eminent among the New England clergymen.

 In person, Roger Sherman was tall his form was erect and well proportioned; his complexion fair, and his countenance manly and agreeable. Though reserved pnd taciturn in soclaintercourse,h he could not be taxed with austerity; nor with want of liberality, though frugal and abstemious. On all occasions his chief objects appeared to be the welfare of his country, and the triumph of justice.

sand dollars TS"-mOulderS m the city cnurcn yard-and his name is forgotten upon the exchange. ENEAS.

 4 D;lcmma.-Mr. Joseph Morgan, keeper of the Exchange Coffee House in Hartford, man ofproperty and respecta- bility, and one of the Directors of the Et- na Insurance Company, was recently in Upper Canada on important business for that office. Being called by name at one of the public houses, by-standers instantly suppusing that he was no less parsonage than the real Captain Morgan, in full life. The conclusion was natural that he would secret himself if their suspicious should be made known to him--They therefore kept dark, till darkness overcome the day, and "nature's soft nurse" had visited the pillow of MT. Morgan and crooked his senses in forgetfulness." At midnight, ''that dread hour," ushered into his bed chamber with suitable number of minis ters of justice ,roused him from his innocent dreams, ordered him to accoutre himself for march to Sir Peregrine Maitland, who had enjoined upon them the delivery to him of the lost, but now restored Morgan. It was in vain that the unarmed prisoner protested that he was not the real Morgan they were in search of-that he had writ ten no book upon masonry-and that he had never before been seized and threaten ed to be taken off to places unknown against his will. But all would not do; he aOas the lost Morgan, and must go before ma gistrate & prove himself innocent of having been runaway with from Batavia this be- ing agreed, Morgan readily satisfied the ma gistrate that he was from the land of steady habits,'' and there upon obtained his re- lease, returned to his couch, slept it out till morning, ,and reached his family and friends at Hartford without further molestation. This perhaps explains the origin of the report that the unfortunate Morgan had

 been discovered safe and sound in Canada Statesman.

WYE have this day agreed with Doctors, w John M. West, Samuel R. Childs, & Samuel Buell., to attend on and furnish to all Paupers within the town of Litchfeld. for whom the town ought to provide, all necessa- ty medicine, medical and surgical aid, for one year from date; and we shall not pay to any other person for any such services or medi- cine furnished on account of said town dur ing said time.

 OZTAS LEWIS,

 WILLIAM BEEBE, N''e"'

 SIMEON SANFORD,

 PHINEAS LORD, A"''J''"' LitchReld, March 23, 1927. Al
NOTICE.

ROaER SHERMAN was born on the lSth OI April, 172l, at NewtOG in Massachusetts, the residence of his father, farmer ln niOderate circumstances. Roger enjoyed no other eu- ,,cat;on than the very limited one which the common country schools of New-Engiand afforded at that period. In his early boyhood he was apprenticed to shoemaker ana ne followed the same trade for some tune after he was twenty one years of age lie recet- ed from nature a vigorous and Inqn'sitlVe mino' the energies of which were net to be repres- s.d even by the drudgery of his mechanical labour. Books happened to be within his reach. such as tended to enlarge and fcrtify the understanding and with them he contrl- we'd, like Dr. Franklin, to gratify his thirst for knowledge, while he performed his work as an apprentice. Before he had reached his ma iority he became even proficient in geOgTa- phy, the mathematics, and the principles of moral science. Politics and the law equally engaged his attention, and in both he rose, as we shall see in the sequel to great emnence the more honorable as it was marked by su- perior usefulness and uniform public virtue. In no stage of his long career did he ever dis play the least desire to conceal the nature of his first calling, nor any pride in his transition to the most digniied pursuits and stations. During the revolutionary war, he W as placed on a committee of Congress to investigate cer- tain army accounts, among which were some relating to contract for the supply of shoes. He told the committee that the charges were exorbitant, which he prove by specifilng the cost of the different materials and the work manship. Perceiving that the minuteness & confidence with which this was done excited some surprise, he informed the committee that he was by trade shoemaker, and was perfectly acquainted with the cost of the arti- cles.

 At the decease of his father he was only nineteen years of age, and yet the mainte- nance of mother and a numerous family of brothers and sisters devolved chiefly on him :; charge which he bore with success, owing to his regular industry in the cultivation of the paternal acres and his skill as an artisan. In l743, it was deemed advisable for the family to dispose of their property at Newton. and remove to New Milford, Litchfeld County Connecticut.-There relinquishing his trade as a shoemaker. he commenced at once thu business of country merchant; and opened shop in connection with an elder brother. IT l745, two years after his removal into the colony of Connecticut, he was appointed q surveyor of lands for the county in which he resided-an advancement due to his mathe- nautical studies. Astronomical calculations oi SO early date as the year 1748 have been discovered among his papers. He made them for an Almanac then published in NewYork, which he supplied thus for several consecutive years.

 At the age of 28, he married respectable female, who gave him a numerous offspring Before this event, by private application to law books and enquiry into rules of practice. he had rendered himself no mean counsellor for his neighbors, and acquired no small repu- tation for legal learning and capacity. After his elevation to the bench, he often recurred with pleasure to the moment he appeared for the first time in the presence of regular law yer. An acquaintance happening to require the assistance of one, Mir. Sherman, who Was going to the county town, was commissioned to seek out the best. Before he left home he digested the case in writing and as he stated it to the gentleman whom he consulted, he frequently resorted to his manuscript, which wns at length demanded from curiosity. The lawyer, after reading it, remarked. with an air of surprise, that with few alterations in form, it would be equal 10 any petition which he could himself prepare and when he had asked some questions concerning his situation and views in life, advised him to adopt the profession of the law Such encouragement was not without its effect in awakening his ambition and concentrating his attention :-| his friends were as eager as himself that he should be a lawyer; and matters were so soon ripened, that in 1754, he was admitted in the courts to practice. In the following year he was placed in the commission of the peace of New-Milford, and chosen by the freemen to represent them in the colonial assembly. This was the commencement of his public career, at the thirty-third year of his age.

 He continued to practice the law with pro- fit and reputation until 1759, when he was ap- pointed judge of the Court of Common Pleas of the county. In 1761 he removed from New-Milford to New-Haven, a better sphere of action, in which he quickly attained all that he could desire. The town of New-Ha,en elected him repeatedly to the legislature. In l765, he was appointed one of the judges of the Court of Common Pleas. He became treasurer of the College, and receiv ed the hen orary degree of master of arts. He had large share in the legislative proceedings. not only as regarded the concerns of Connecticut, but those of the Colon'rs in general His sound, sagaeious sense, his comprehensive informa- ton, his close reasoning, enforced by plain, manly delivery, and his decision on principal questions, acquired for him an almost unri- vailed authority in the. Connecticut councils. In i766, he was raised to the office of judge of the Superior Court. station which he re- talned 2S years, and filled with an ahfv and
BIOGRAPHICAL NOTICE.

Situated in VERGENNES, in the State of Vermont, upon the falls of Otter Creek. The focal situation of this Furnace is as good, if not better, than any in the State of Vermont, being in the village of Vergennes, and with in one hundred rods of water carriage to any part of the Lake, or New-York, by way of the Northern Canal. The best of OAR for making Stove Plates or Hollow Ware, may be had within few miles, or may be brought from the shores of Lake Champlain, by wa ter. Coal in great abundance may be had on short notice. The Furnace will be sold ve- ry low. Only part of the purchase money will be wanted this spring, the remainder in yearly payments. For further particulars inquire of MOSES COUPON, 40 of Fair-Hayen, Rutland Co. Vt.

 'I am worth one hundred thousand dol- lars ! l was just sixty-6ve last Christmas, 1 am yet hale and strong. Go to: I'll withdraw from the bustle of the world, and the busy hum of the exchange. I'll retire and enjoy myself

 Good y continued old Jacobs, manful- ly striding up the mountains side-'Good! l am worth at least one hundred thousand dollars! Aye here I'll build me a warm mansion-there, I'll plant my orchard on this side will have my summer-house round younder angle, we'll run up the stable-and here will dig my ice-house. What must have all those unsightly wooden houses blocking up my view No matter can purchase them of my broth CT merchant, MT. Hicks and then every one ofthem shall come down.

 Consider, sir, for moment.' observed old Jacobs land agent, consider what will these poor people do, ifyou pull down their huts 1? 'Do-do'-let them do as they can: 'tis no concern of mine. And hark ye Mir. Agent, do you see that mill, that makes such a noisy clack do you see, I say, how its wheel obstructs the stream that wa ters my grounds ? Come no words-that shall come down too.'

averv respect.-There were few in that illus trious assembly whose judgment was more respected or whose opinions had more weight. He was very able and logical debater in that body steady in the principles of the revolution; al ways at the post of duty much employed in the business of Committees, and particularly was of the Committee of Dr. Franklin, MT. J. Adams and myself for preparing the Decla- ration of Independence" He was also suc- cessively member of War and Ordnance, of the Treasury board and of the Marine com mittee. During the whole revolutionary strug- gle, he manifested a dauntless spirit as we'll as an ndefatigable zeal.

 In 1784 when New Haven was incorpora- ted, he was elected to the office of Mayor of the city, which he held for the remainder ol his life. About the same period, he was as- sociated with another of the Judges of the Superior Court, in the task of revising and digesting the statutes 0f Connecticut, SO as to produce an improved code for the State. This oppressive service was performed with his usual conscientiousness and success. In 1787, he was appointed a delegate to the General Convention to frame the Federal Constitution of the United States. One of his colleagues was the celebrated Oliver Els worth, who held the office of associate judge of the same court, and wLo as he himself de clared had made MT. Sherman his model in his youth. The venerable President Adams

 mentions that '' he never saw two men more

 alike, except that the late Chief Justice Els worth had the advantage of a liberal educa ton, and somewhat more extensive reading , Both were conspicuous in the Convention fo , the earnestness and usefulness of their coop eration in tho glorious work of that body Sherman wrote series of essays under thu 1 signature of" Citizen," in favor of the con

 stitution, which are affirmed to have materi

 ally contributed to procure that full majority

 by which it was ratified in Connecticut. Wher I it went into operation, he was elected rep resentative in Congress, and though vergins toward his 7Oth year, took deep interest & active part in the proceedings of the new House.

 At the expiration of his first term, he was translated to the Senate, among whom he was never found backward, either in debate oI committee service, touching the various impOr- tant subjects which then came under discus sion. Providence, however, allowed him but two years more of a race thus signaized, in public and private, by dispositions and endea- yours which were well adapted to propitiate Divine favour for another life. He died at New-Haven, on the Sd July, 179S, aged sev- enty two. He had been from his youth de- vout christian, and constant reader of the Scriptures. He maintained correspondence, at different times, on abstruse points of the ology and metaphysics, with some of the most erudite and eminent among the New England clergymen.

 In person, Roger Sherman was tall his form was erect and well proportioned; his complexion fair, and his countenance manly and agreeable. Though reserved pnd taciturn in soclaintercourse,h he could not be taxed with austerity; nor with want of liberality, though frugal and abstemious. On all occasions his chief objects appeared to be the welfare of his country, and the triumph of justice.

sand dollars TS"-mOulderS m the city cnurcn yard-and his name is forgotten upon the exchange. ENEAS.

 4 D;lcmma.-Mr. Joseph Morgan, keeper of the Exchange Coffee House in Hartford, man ofproperty and respecta- bility, and one of the Directors of the Et- na Insurance Company, was recently in Upper Canada on important business for that office. Being called by name at one of the public houses, by-standers instantly suppusing that he was no less parsonage than the real Captain Morgan, in full life. The conclusion was natural that he would secret himself if their suspicious should be made known to him--They therefore kept dark, till darkness overcome the day, and "nature's soft nurse" had visited the pillow of MT. Morgan and crooked his senses in forgetfulness." At midnight, ''that dread hour," ushered into his bed chamber with suitable number of minis ters of justice ,roused him from his innocent dreams, ordered him to accoutre himself for march to Sir Peregrine Maitland, who had enjoined upon them the delivery to him of the lost, but now restored Morgan. It was in vain that the unarmed prisoner protested that he was not the real Morgan they were in search of-that he had writ ten no book upon masonry-and that he had never before been seized and threaten ed to be taken off to places unknown against his will. But all would not do; he aOas the lost Morgan, and must go before ma gistrate & prove himself innocent of having been runaway with from Batavia this be- ing agreed, Morgan readily satisfied the ma gistrate that he was from the land of steady habits,'' and there upon obtained his re- lease, returned to his couch, slept it out till morning, ,and reached his family and friends at Hartford without further molestation. This perhaps explains the origin of the report that the unfortunate Morgan had

 been discovered safe and sound in Canada Statesman.

full articles.headline: BIOGRAPHICAL NOTICE.
full articles.article:
ROaER SHERMAN was born on the lSth OI April, 172l, at NewtOG in Massachusetts, the residence of his father, farmer ln niOderate circumstances. Roger enjoyed no other eu- ,,cat;on than the very limited one which the common country schools of New-Engiand afforded at that period. In his early boyhood he was apprenticed to shoemaker ana ne followed the same trade for some tune after he was twenty one years of age lie recet- ed from nature a vigorous and Inqn'sitlVe mino' the energies of which were net to be repres- s.d even by the drudgery of his mechanical labour. Books happened to be within his reach. such as tended to enlarge and fcrtify the understanding and with them he contrl- we'd, like Dr. Franklin, to gratify his thirst for knowledge, while he performed his work as an apprentice. Before he had reached his ma iority he became even proficient in geOgTa- phy, the mathematics, and the principles of moral science. Politics and the law equally engaged his attention, and in both he rose, as we shall see in the sequel to great emnence the more honorable as it was marked by su- perior usefulness and uniform public virtue. In no stage of his long career did he ever dis play the least desire to conceal the nature of his first calling, nor any pride in his transition to the most digniied pursuits and stations. During the revolutionary war, he W as placed on a committee of Congress to investigate cer- tain army accounts, among which were some relating to contract for the supply of shoes. He told the committee that the charges were exorbitant, which he prove by specifilng the cost of the different materials and the work manship. Perceiving that the minuteness & confidence with which this was done excited some surprise, he informed the committee that he was by trade shoemaker, and was perfectly acquainted with the cost of the arti- cles.

 At the decease of his father he was only nineteen years of age, and yet the mainte- nance of mother and a numerous family of brothers and sisters devolved chiefly on him :; charge which he bore with success, owing to his regular industry in the cultivation of the paternal acres and his skill as an artisan. In l743, it was deemed advisable for the family to dispose of their property at Newton. and remove to New Milford, Litchfeld County Connecticut.-There relinquishing his trade as a shoemaker. he commenced at once thu business of country merchant; and opened shop in connection with an elder brother. IT l745, two years after his removal into the colony of Connecticut, he was appointed q surveyor of lands for the county in which he resided-an advancement due to his mathe- nautical studies. Astronomical calculations oi SO early date as the year 1748 have been discovered among his papers. He made them for an Almanac then published in NewYork, which he supplied thus for several consecutive years.

 At the age of 28, he married respectable female, who gave him a numerous offspring Before this event, by private application to law books and enquiry into rules of practice. he had rendered himself no mean counsellor for his neighbors, and acquired no small repu- tation for legal learning and capacity. After his elevation to the bench, he often recurred with pleasure to the moment he appeared for the first time in the presence of regular law yer. An acquaintance happening to require the assistance of one, Mir. Sherman, who Was going to the county town, was commissioned to seek out the best. Before he left home he digested the case in writing and as he stated it to the gentleman whom he consulted, he frequently resorted to his manuscript, which wns at length demanded from curiosity. The lawyer, after reading it, remarked. with an air of surprise, that with few alterations in form, it would be equal 10 any petition which he could himself prepare and when he had asked some questions concerning his situation and views in life, advised him to adopt the profession of the law Such encouragement was not without its effect in awakening his ambition and concentrating his attention :-| his friends were as eager as himself that he should be a lawyer; and matters were so soon ripened, that in 1754, he was admitted in the courts to practice. In the following year he was placed in the commission of the peace of New-Milford, and chosen by the freemen to represent them in the colonial assembly. This was the commencement of his public career, at the thirty-third year of his age.

 He continued to practice the law with pro- fit and reputation until 1759, when he was ap- pointed judge of the Court of Common Pleas of the county. In 1761 he removed from New-Milford to New-Haven, a better sphere of action, in which he quickly attained all that he could desire. The town of New-Ha,en elected him repeatedly to the legislature. In l765, he was appointed one of the judges of the Court of Common Pleas. He became treasurer of the College, and receiv ed the hen orary degree of master of arts. He had large share in the legislative proceedings. not only as regarded the concerns of Connecticut, but those of the Colon'rs in general His sound, sagaeious sense, his comprehensive informa- ton, his close reasoning, enforced by plain, manly delivery, and his decision on principal questions, acquired for him an almost unri- vailed authority in the. Connecticut councils. In i766, he was raised to the office of judge of the Superior Court. station which he re- talned 2S years, and filled with an ahfv and

full articles.headline: FOR SALE, A BLAST FURNACE;
full articles.article:
Situated in VERGENNES, in the State of Vermont, upon the falls of Otter Creek. The focal situation of this Furnace is as good, if not better, than any in the State of Vermont, being in the village of Vergennes, and with in one hundred rods of water carriage to any part of the Lake, or New-York, by way of the Northern Canal. The best of OAR for making Stove Plates or Hollow Ware, may be had within few miles, or may be brought from the shores of Lake Champlain, by wa ter. Coal in great abundance may be had on short notice. The Furnace will be sold ve- ry low. Only part of the purchase money will be wanted this spring, the remainder in yearly payments. For further particulars inquire of MOSES COUPON, 40 of Fair-Hayen, Rutland Co. Vt.

 BENJAMIN REEDS ESTATE.

 The Hon. Court of Probate for the Dis trct of Sharon has assigned Friday the SOth of March instant, at o'clock in the forenoon, at the Probate Office, in Salisbury, for set ting the administration accounts of the ad- ministrators upon the estate of

 BENJAMIN REED,

 late of Sharon, in said District, deceased, when and where all persons interested may appear and be heard thereon.

 By erder of Court,

 PRUDENCE REED, Admin

 DANIEL REED, istrators.

 Sharon, March 14, 1897. 40

 Probate Court, March A., 1927. Estate of Amos Barnum, late of Kent, de- ceased.

 THE Administrator represents the Estate l insolvent, and prays the appointment of Commissioners thereon

 Ordered, That Commissioners to receive and examine the claims of the creditors of said Estate be appointed at the Probate Office in New Milford, on the 9th day of April 1897, at 10 o'clock, forenoon: of which all persons in interest will take notice and appear if they see cause and be heard thereon.

 A true copy of Record, 40 Attest NATHANIEL PERRY, Clerk.
